title: 114_hr184
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Indians should be granted full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe, along with the benefits, privileges, and immunities that come with this status. The Lumbee Indians should be granted full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. Laws and regulations applicable to Indian tribes will now apply to the Lumbee Tribe and its members. Other groups of Indians in specific counties may also petition for tribal acknowledgement. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized tribes. Members residing in specific North Carolina counties are considered to be on or near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will work with the tribe to determine needs for eligible services, submitting a statement to Congress after verifying the tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe's service population will be defined by the tribal roll verified by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary may take land into trust for the tribe in Robeson County, North Carolina, for on-reservation trust acquisition. The tribe is prohibited from conducting gaming activities. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is prohibited from conducting gaming activities under any Federal law or regulations. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the tribe. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers from the State after consulting with the Attorney General. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States, subject to an agreement with the State of North Carolina. This transfer would not take effect until 2 years after the agreement. The provisions of this section do not impact the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized to implement this Act.
